More Notes: Average impact of 1 degree of variability
Day-to-day temperature variability reduces regional growth rate by at least five percentage points per extra degree Celsius of variability in a given year and region.
Coefficient for T_r : ~T_r;y (interacted with seasonal temperature difference)
Coefficient for T_r :δ /C22T_r;y (annual average temperature change interacted)
Coefficient for T_r :δT_r ;y/C01 (interacted with seasonal temperature difference)
Marginal change varies by GDP/capita and seasonal temp diff.
Spring, summer, and autumn have significant effects.

Marginal losses from day-to-day temperature variability are generally larger for regions in low-income nations compared with those in higher-income nations.  The difference is more pronounced in higher-latitude countries.  Value estimated visually from figure.

Marginal losses from day-to-day temperature variability are generally smaller for regions in high-income nations compared with those in lower-income nations. The marginal losses show a stronger dependence on the seasonal temperature difference.  Value estimated visually from figure.
Negative impacts of day-to-day variability persist for at least two years following the initial shock. Value is illustrative only.
